docs.lead_paragraph: YOU REMIND ME OF ME By Dan Chaon 356 pages. Ballantine Books. $24.95 Six-year-old Jonah Doyle is playing with his Doberman pinscher, Elizabeth, at the start of Dan Chaon's delicately hypnotic new novel. If this sounds like an ordinary moment, it is not. For one thing, there is the photorealistic vividness of Mr. Chaon's intimately observant descriptions. (''He loved her rubbery black lips with their amphibious, warty nodes nestled near her back teeth.'') For another, this innocent encounter will turn lethal. The dog will die. The boy will be scarred forever.

headline.main: Brother, Where Art Thou? A Loner's Quest for Family

docs.lead_paragraph: ''What to Do for Healthy Teeth,'' by Dr. Sadie S. Mestman and Dr. Ariella D. Herman. Institute for Healthcare Advancement, $12.95. ''The Perfect Smile,'' by Dr. James H. Doundoulakis and Warren Strugatch. Healthy Living Books, $15.95. Books about dentistry have never cornered the health book market, perhaps because for many people the dentist's chair still inspires fear.
docs.abstract: Dr Sadie S Mestman and Dr Ariella D Herman book What to Do for Healthy Teeth is easy to read guide to oral health; The Perfect Smile, written by Dr James H Doundoulakis and Warren Strugatch, examines all aspects of cosmetic dentistry and importance of attractive smile; photos (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Weeks This Last On Week Week List Fiction 1 1 60 THE DA VINCI CODE, by Dan Brown. (Doubleday, $24.95.) The murder of a curator at the Louvre leads to a trail of clues found in the work of Leonardo and to the discovery of a centuries-old secret society. 2 1 THE NARROWS, by Michael Connelly. (Little, Brown, $25.95.) Harry Bosch, the former Los Angeles police detective, and the F.B.I. agent Rachel Walling must contend with the serial killer known as the Poet. 3 2 33 THE FIVE PEOPLE YOU MEET IN HEAVEN, by Mitch Albom. (Hyperion, $19.95.) An old man who died while trying to rescue a little girl from danger discovers that all will be explained to him in the afterlife. 4 4 5 NIGHTTIME IS MY TIME, by Mary Higgins Clark. (Simon & Schuster, $25.95.) Determined to avenge himself on the girls who rejected him in high school, a crazed killer targets his 20th class reunion. 5 3 6 GLORIOUS APPEARING, by Tim LaHaye and Jerry B. Jenkins. (Tyndale, $24.99.) In the 12th volume of the ''Left Behind'' series, in which the forces of good battle the forces of evil, the Second Coming occurs. 6 5 19 ANGELS & DEMONS, by Dan Brown. (Atria, $19.95.) A Harvard scholar tries to save the Vatican from the machinations of an underground society. 7 1 MEMORIAL DAY, by Vince Flynn. (Atria, $25.95.) A counterterrorism expert rushes to prevent an attack on American soil. 8 1 THE SUMMER I DARED, by Barbara Delinsky. (Scribner, $24.95.) Having survived a deadly boating accident off the coast of Maine, a wife and mother begins to question her priorities. 9 7 2 JUST ONE LOOK, by Harlan Coben. (Dutton, $25.95.) A woman's unearthing of a mysterious photograph leads to the disappearance of her husband and a confrontation with a coldblooded killer. 10 8 3 THE FULL CUPBOARD OF LIFE, by Alexander McCall Smith. (Pantheon, $19.95.) The fifth novel in the No. 1 Ladies' Detective Agency series. 11 1 THE PAID COMPANION, by Amanda Quick. (Putnam, $24.95.) In early-19th-century England, the Earl of St. Merryn hires a woman to pose as his fiancée. 12 6 3 THERAPY, by Jonathan Kellerman. (Ballantine, $26.95.) The psychologist-detective Alex Delaware investigates the murder of a couple in a lovers' lane. 13 12 14 THE LAST JUROR, by John Grisham. (Doubleday, $27.95.) In Clanton, Miss., someone is killing off the jurors who sent a man to prison for rape and murder. 14 9 5 BERGDORF BLONDES, by Plum Sykes. (Miramax/Hyperion, $23.95.) The romantic adventures of an upper-class Manhattan woman and her best friend as they go hunting for ''P.H.'s'' (prospective husbands). 15 1 THE JANE AUSTEN BOOK CLUB, by Karen Joy Fowler. (Marian Wood/Putnam, $23.95.) The tale of six people who belong to a reading group in California. Weeks This Last On Week Week List Nonfiction 1 1 3 PLAN OF ATTACK, by Bob Woodward. (Simon & Schuster, $28.) A behind-the-scenes account of the Bush administration's decision making as it drew up plans to invade Iraq and overthrow Saddam Hussein. 2 2 5 EATS, SHOOTS & LEAVES, by Lynne Truss. (Gotham, $17.50.) An Englishwoman expounds on the use and misuse of punctuation marks. 3 7 4 FOUNDING MOTHERS, by Cokie Roberts. (Morrow, $24.95.) The ABC News commentator details the lives of the many women (Abigail Adams and Martha Washington among them) who ''raised our nation.'' 4 3 4 THREE WEEKS WITH MY BROTHER, by Nicholas Sparks and Micah Sparks. (Warner, $22.) The novelist and his sibling describe their trip around the world. 5 5 2 ALEXANDER HAMILTON, by Ron Chernow. (Penguin Press, $35.) A biography of the first Treasury secretary and chief author of The Federalist Papers. 6 4 7 AGAINST ALL ENEMIES, by Richard A. Clarke. (Free Press, $27.) President Bush's former counterterrorism coordinator criticizes the administration's handling of events before and after the 9/11 attacks. 7 1 REWRITING HISTORY, by Dick Morris with Eileen McGann. (ReganBooks/HarperCollins, $24.95.) A former adviser to President Bill Clinton ''deconstructs'' Hillary Clinton's autobiography, ''Living History.'' 8 6 6 WORSE THAN WATERGATE, by John W. Dean. (Little, Brown, $22.95.) The man who served as counsel to President Richard Nixon offers an indictment of the Bush administration. 9 8 3 *ON THE DOWN LOW, by J. L. King with Karen Hunter. (Broadway, $21.95.) Exploring the lives of ostensibly straight black men who have sex with men, and the health consequences for the black community. 10 9 2 BELLY LAUGHS, by Jenny McCarthy. (Da Capo/Lifelong, $18.) The former MTV host discusses ''the naked truth about pregnancy and childbirth.'' 11 1 THE POLITICS OF TRUTH, by Joseph Wilson. (Carroll & Graf, $26.) A memoir by the American diplomat whose wife's covert status as a C.I.A. operative was disclosed by officials in the Bush administration. 12 11 2 SECRETS OF THE CODE, edited by Dan Burstein. (CDS Books/Squibnocket, $21.95.) Essays by a variety of experts -- theologians, art historians, scientists -- on themes relating to ''The Da Vinci Code.'' 13 1 GRACE AND POWER, by Sally Bedell Smith. (Random House, $29.95.) A portrait of John F. Kennedy and Jacqueline Kennedy in the White House. 14 10 5 CADDY FOR LIFE, by John Feinstein. (Little, Brown, $25.95.) The story of Bruce Edwards, Tom Watson's longtime caddie, who died last month. 15 12 6 TEN MINUTES FROM NORMAL, by Karen Hughes. (Viking, $25.95.) The autobiography of a close adviser to President Bush. Weeks This Last On Week Week List Children's Chapter Books 1 2 9 SUMMER OF THE SEA SERPENT, by Mary Pope Osborne. Illustrated by Sal Murdocca. (Stepping Stone/ Random House, $11.95.) Merlin sends Jack and Annie on an adventure in the magic treehouse. (Ages 6 to 9) 2 1 37 ERAGON, by Christopher Paolini. (Knopf, $18.95.) A boy and a young dragon must navigate a bewildering world of dark powers. (Ages 12 and up) 3 4 2 SHADOWMANCER, by G. P. Taylor. (Putnam, $16.99.) An English vicar devises a plan to control the world -- and to control God as well. (Ages 12 and up) 4 8 47 HARRY POTTER AND THE ORDER OF THE PHOENIX, by J. K. Rowling. (Levine/Scholastic, $29.99.) A British teenager confronts dark discoveries at witchcraft school. (Ages 10 and up) 5 3 6 THE IRONWOOD TREE, by Tony DiTerlizzi and Holly Black. (Simon & Schuster, $9.95.) Volume 4 of ''The Spiderwick Chronicles.'' (Ages 6 to 10) 6 5 22 THE TALE OF DESPEREAUX, by Kate DiCamillo. Illustrated by Timothy Basil Ering. (Candlewick, $17.99.) A mouse, a rat and a simple servant girl embark on a magical journey. (Ages 10 and up) 7 9 2 THE SUPERNATURALIST, by Eoin Colfer. (Miramax/Hyperion, $16.95.) In the future, a teenager battles oppressors and deadly parasites. (Ages 12 and up) 8 6 7 PRINCESS IN PINK, by Meg Cabot. (HarperCollins, $15.99.) Volume 5 of ''The Princess Diaries.'' (Ages 12 and up) 9 7 33 THE SLIPPERY SLOPE, by Lemony Snicket. (HarperCollins, $10.99.) In Book 10, the three Baudelaire siblings encounter much unpleasantness during journeys up and down mountains. (Ages 10 and up) 10 10 2 HUNTERS OF THE DUSK, by Darren Shan. (Little, Brown, $15.95.) Volume 7 of the ''Cirque du Freak'' series, featuring elite vampires. (Ages 10 to 14) Rankings reflect sales, for the week ended May 8, at almost 4,000 bookstores plus wholesalers serving 50,000 other retailers (gift shops, department stores, newsstands, supermarkets), statistically weighted to represent all such outlets nationwide. An asterisk (*) indicates that a book's sales are barely distinguishable from those of the book above. A dagger (+) indicates that some bookstores report receiving bulk orders. Expanded rankings are available at The New York Times on the Web: nytimes.com/books. Best-seller lists for children's picture books, children's chapter books and children's paperbacks, respectively, are published in rotation on succeeding weeks; all three lists appear each week on the Book Review's Web site. Publishers have provided the age designations for their best-selling children's titles. Rankings for children's paperbacks do not include serials.

docs.lead_paragraph: ON Wednesday, at a lunch at Cipriani 42nd Street to benefit the obstetric unit of New York-Presbyterian Hospital, a table of women in their 20's and 30's hovered over chicken salad and engaged in the polite conversation suitable for lunching ladies. Divorce, death, social scandal -- that sort of thing. But when they got to the subject of pregnancy, all that white-gloves-and-tea-sandwiches politesse went out the window.

headline.main: The Nine Months of Living Anxiously

docs.abstract: Article on 'pregnancy paranoia' that is arising among some pregnant woman over dozens of foods, activities and procedures believed to threaten fetal health; list, thanks to ever-growing body of scientific research and old wives tales thriving on Internet, ranges from foods and underwear to electronic devices; photos (M)
docs.snippet: ON Wednesday, at a lunch at Cipriani 42nd Street to benefit the obstetric unit of New York-Presbyterian Hospital, a table of women in their 20's and 30's hovered over chicken salad and engaged in the polite conversation suitable for lunching ladies....

docs.lead_paragraph: A partnership of about 150 obstetrician-gynecologists in Connecticut announced this week that they planned to add a $500 surcharge to each pregnant woman's bill starting in September. By announcing the surcharge, the group hopes to influence lawmakers to pass ''meaningful reforms'' to reduce the cost of malpractice insurance, said Nancy P. Bernstein, president and chief executive of the partnership, Women's Health Connecticut. The Fairfield County Medical Association, a professional organization representing almost 2,000 physicians in every medical specialty, also announced a position on surcharges: If doctors want to charge patients a fee for items or services not covered by insurance -- such as phoning in prescriptions after hours -- they should, said Mark S. Thompson, the association's executive director.

headline.main: Pushing Insurance Reform With a $500 Surcharge

docs.abstract: About 150 obstetrician-gynecologists belonging to Women's Health Connecticut plan to place $500 surcharge on bills of pregnant women starting in September in effort to pressure state lawmakers to reduce cost of malpractice insurance; Fairfield County Medical Association encourages its 2,000 members to charge patients for services not covered by insurance; Atty Gen Richard Blumenthal says that under physicians' contract agreement with insurance providers, enrollees in state or private insurance plans cannot be billed for any sums beyond what insurance company would pay, excluding deductibles and co-payments (M)
